channel.title: Destructive interference
channel.description: In physics, if two waves destructively interfere energy appears to be lost. Where does this energy go?

item.title: Destructive interference
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:18, topic:318074”][quote author=yakman link=topic=414580.msg3053094#msg3053094 date=1260230949]
Remember this key point – if two waves completely cancel each other out, you do NOT have two waves. You have no wave.
[/quote]

sure, but what happens to the energy transferred from the emitter (lets say a speaker)?[/quote]
if it was two waves cancelling out you dont hear it, thats why if you set up two speakers with distance between them and you stand lets say 10 feet away and move backwards and forwards the volume of what you can hear will change because of the interference both constructive and destructive

Read full topic

yakman:

Remember this key point – if two waves completely cancel each other out, you do NOT have two waves. You have no wave.

sure, but what happens to the energy transferred from the emitter (lets say a speaker)?

Read full topic

item.title: Destructive interference
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

A hidden assumption here goes something like this. “There are two waves, each containing energy.”

This is where you go wrong. If destructive interference causes complete cancellation of the wave phenomena, there are not two waves. There is no wave.

When there is no wave phenomena, there is no energy. It doesn’t matter if it is because of destructive interference or because no waves were created in the first place.

Remember this key point – if two waves completely cancel each other out, you do NOT have two waves. You have no wave.

hope that answers your question.

Read full topic

afaik you can never have complete destructive inference and there will always be some constructive inference somewhere

item.title: Destructive interference
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

So you’re saying that the energy remains in that form but cannot be detected because of how it is ‘positioned’, so to speak? No wonder I couldn’t figure out an answer, I just knew about constructive and destructive interference in black and white.

Read full topic

item.title: Destructive interference
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

@smarter people: poke holes in this, im not a physicist

@inertia as i understand it, wave interference is always a matter of redistributing energy, nothing is ever “lost” or “gained”, except from the perception from a certain point. ie, if you perceive constructive interference, somewhere else in the same system there is destructive interference.

think about those active noise reduction headphones you can buy. they (sort of) work on this principle, inverting the phase of a recording of the noise outside the headphones and mixing it with what you hear inside the headphones to isolate just what people want to hear. however, they are designed so that the area where the waves “perfectly” (yknow what i mean, not perfectly but as good as) destruct is the area where your ears sit. if you were to somehow modify the headphones so that the electronics was the same but your ear sat in a different position they wouldn’t work - somewhere else in this system there is constructive interference and that’s where your energy went - its just been distributed like anything else.

again, im not a physicist, just a wannabe audio engineer, so this has a bunch of dumb mistakes in it im almost certain, but its good enough as a working theory

Read full topic

item.title: Destructive interference
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

If two similar cars crash into eachother with the same speed, the energy can’t go forward so it goes to the sides.

Read full topic

item.title: Destructive interference
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

[quote=“R.I.P RSC, post:9, topic:318074”]Bending steel takes a lot of energy. Two cars in a frontal collision usually are bent to the sides, like a drop of water that falls on the ground. In slow motion, you see it spreading over the floor for a while.[/quote]It only takes energy because the molecules have to me shifted around, which releases heat energy. If a material takes less energy to bend this is simply because the intermolecular structure is not as strong and less energy is required to move the molecules and releases less heat.

Read full topic

item.description:

item.title: Destructive interference
item.dc:creator: @inertia inertia
item.description:
@inertia wrote:

[quote=“sanga282, post:7, topic:318074”][quote author=inertia link=topic=414580.msg3051792#msg3051792 date=1260130694]
Well if two cars hit each other with opposite momentum, their momentum will cancel out but energy is still transferred as a mixture of negative momentum (rebound), sound energy and heat energy.
[/quote]
if two cars hit each other at equal speeds and they of the same weight then they will stop, you also cant have negative momentum in that instance because both cars are travelling in opposite directions, for there to be negative momentum you’d have to define which car originally had positive and negative momentum[/quote]The energy has to go somewhere though, and as I said it is transferred as heat and sound. If there is any elasticity in the collision, which there undoubtedly will be, the cars will rebound because the energy they used transferred as elastic potential energy will be transferred back to kinetic energy.

Read full topic

item.title: Destructive interference
item.dc:creator: @sanga282 sanga282
item.description:
@sanga282 wrote:

inertia:

Well if two cars hit each other with opposite momentum, their momentum will cancel out but energy is still transferred as a mixture of negative momentum (rebound), sound energy and heat energy.

if two cars hit each other at equal speeds and they of the same weight then they will stop, you also cant have negative momentum in that instance because both cars are travelling in opposite directions, for there to be negative momentum you’d have to define which car originally had positive and negative momentum

Read full topic
